details: A classic Taiwanese breakfast usually includes warm soy milk (豆漿) paired with crispy baked flatbread (燒餅) or a chewy egg crepe (蛋餅). It’s simple, comforting, and a must-try way to start the day like a local.

Name_EN: Bubble Milk Tea 珍珠奶茶
details: Most famous drink in Taiwan with milk tea and chewy tapioca pearls. Sweet, fun, and customizable, it’s a global icon that started on the island.”
Taiwan’s most iconic street food — it smells bold but tastes surprisingly delicious, crispy outside and tender inside. Dare to try it, and you might just get hooked!
Douhua is a silky tofu pudding served with sweet syrup and toppings like peanuts or tapioca. Light, refreshing, and comforting.
A mountain of shaved ice topped with fruits, beans, or sweet syrup. It’s Taiwan’s ultimate summer treat to cool down in the heat.
The Ultimate Night-Out Feast! A lively dining style where chefs whip up quick, flavorful dishes in blazing woks—perfect for sharing with friends over ice-cold Taiwan Beer.

Taiwan is a tropical paradise where farmers use advanced cultivation techniques and microclimate advantages to grow an incredible variety of fruits—mangoes, pineapples, guavas, and more. You will never find them in any other countries.
Savory congee is a rice porridge simmered with ingredients like dried shrimp, pork, or vegetables for a comforting, umami-rich flavor.

Name_EN: Plain congee with small side dishes
details: This offers a lighter option—soft rice porridge paired with pickled vegetables, tofu, and peanuts, reflecting the rustic simplicity of Taiwanese home cooking.
All Taiwanese grow up with this! Inspired by Sichuan flavors, Taiwanese chefs added soy-braised beef and local spices for a milder, sweeter taste.
All Taiwanese grow up with this! If you have not tried "melt-in-your-mouth tender", please try this. Pork belly is slow-braised with soy sauce, sugar, and spices for hours.

A Fujianese dish transformed in Taiwan with sweet potato starch for extra chewiness. Experience the joy of Taiwan, a land blessed with rich ocean harvests and the rustic flavors of its countryside—where sweet potatoes and oysters have become true symbols of the island.
Origin of the global street-food star. It is traditional Hakka snack with fluffy steamed bun hugging braised pork belly, pickled veggies, and crushed peanuts
Find out the secret Taiwaneses deep fried the chicken. Bite-sized, crispy, and seasoned with basil. (Shh...We use sweet potato flour to coat the chicken and deep-fried twice)
Named after its “three cups” of seasoning—soy sauce, rice wine, and sesame oil. We also use "Three cups" on other meat/vegetables,
A grilled Taiwanese pork sausage wrapped in sticky rice, a fun and flavorful street-food twist often found at these spots.
Crispy, funky, and with the Taiwanese Kimchi. The special smell is from the fermented process. Dare to try?
Flaky, crispy, and perfect with egg or cheese.
You will never had this anywhere else! Made from mashed sweet potato mixed with tapioca starch for that bouncy texture.
Plant-based twist on a classic. Uses soy protein or mushrooms braised in soy sauce for a meaty texture.
A Buddhist temple dish, cooked without onion or garlic due to Taiwanese Buddha limitation. A colorful mix of veggies and tofu.
Wheat noodles tossed in sesame paste, soy sauce, and vinegar. Perfect for humid summer in Taiwan.
Named after its “three cups” of seasoning—soy sauce, rice wine, and sesame oil. We also use "Three cups" on other meat/vegetables.
Popular in Taipei’s Halal eateries, using beef shank and spice-rich broth. Certified shops serve this iconic dish.
Lamb simmered with Chinese herbs for hours, perfect for winter.
Smoky, tender, brushed with sweet soy glaze.
A simple, homestyle dish with only fresh clams in a ginger-infused broth.
Taiwan’s thriving aquaculture industry makes milkfish a local staple, especially in Tainan. Its flesh is tender yet firm, with a mild sweetness and delicate texture.
